Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: BullyBlocker - Identifying Cyberbullying in Social Networking Sites

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cyberbullying is the most common online risk for adolescents, yet the majority of young people who are bullied online do not tell their parents when it occurs. The goal of the BullyBlocker project is to advance the understanding of how cyberbullying, in particular, and behavioral issues, more broadly, can be effectively identified on social networking sites. This interdisciplinary project integrates advances in computer sciences and key findings from psychological research on cyberbullying to (i) design and implement models for identifying cyberbullying on social networking platforms, and (ii) study usage patterns of automated tools based on these models and their utility for devising and testing new hypotheses about cyberbullying risk factors.

The intellectual merit of this project stems from its synergistic integration of computer and psychological science to address a social problem that negatively impacts adolescents, their families, and society. The project draws on psychological research on cyberbullying risk factors and advances in computer science to enable the development of automated identification models and the integration of these models into an app (BullyBlocker) that notifies parents about their adolescents' risk of cyberbullying. The project also entails the design of mechanisms to generate customized anti-bullying resources for parents and victims, investigation of app usage patterns and parents' attitudes towards automated identification tools, the use of automated tools such as BullyBlocker to devise and test new hypotheses about cyberbullying, and a unique training opportunity that provides graduate and undergraduate students with the scientific scaffolding to develop into recognized interdisciplinary scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rates of cyberbullying have risen steadily, with a majority of teens reporting that they have been bullied or harassed online. The increased prevalence of cyberbullying has occurred in tandem with surges in the use of social networking sites, particularly among youth. The goal of this project was to develop a better understanding of how cyberbullying, specifically, and psychological and ­behavioral issues, more broadly, can be effectively identified on social networking sites. Drawing on advances in computer science and empirical findings from psychology, the primary aims of the project were to: (1) design and implement computational models for identifying cyberbullying on social networking sites, (2) build technological tools (i.e., mobile applications) based on these models that help identify and prevent cyberbullying, and (3) study people’s perceptions of and likelihood of adopting technological tools based on automated cyberbullying identification models.

During the three years of the project, we designed and implemented multiple computational models that shed light on how to identify cyberbullying in social networking sites. These models incorporate psychology research findings on predictors of cyberbullying into state-of-the-art computer science techniques. Some of the key ideas on which these models are based include tailoring cyberbullying detection models to individual social media users, drawing on similarities between users to take peer influence into account, leveraging the hierarchical structure and multi-modal nature of social media interactions, and incorporating temporal information into cyberbullying identification frameworks. We also collected survey data to investigate how social media use behaviors interact with psychological risk factors for cyberbullying and factors predicting parents’ likelihood of using anti-bullying mobile apps.

This project resulted in 8 peer-reviewed papers accepted in top-tier conferences and journals, 6 peer-reviewed research poster presentations, 10 conference/symposium talks, 2 journal articles under review (invited resubmissions with minor revisions), and 2 manuscripts in advanced stages of preparation. It also resulted in the development and release of a new version of an anti-bullying app (the BullyBlocker app), the development of an initial version of a mobile app to strengthen parent-teen relationships, and the initiation of a patent application. Other notable outcomes include a Best Paper Award at a leading workshop on cyber safety, a press release from an international applied math and computing society, the PIs’ nomination for a 2018 Governor’s Award for Innovation, multiple publicly-available social media datasets manually labeled for cyberbullying by trained members of the research team, and a publicly-available hybrid social network generator (to help researchers test predictive models in the absence of widely-available social media data).

The broader impacts of the project also include the innovative research training experience provided to a diverse team of graduate and undergraduate students (63% of them were either women, ethnic minorities, or both) and considerable community outreach. Across the three years, the project included 19 graduate students (12 funded) and 16 undergraduate students (7 funded) representing a range of disciplinary and sociocultural backgrounds. The project resulted in five student-led poster presentations for interdisciplinary student research symposia at Arizona State University (ASU), and every paper/publication and research presentation produced from this project had student co-authors. A student member of the research team also presented a poster for the undergraduate track of the 2019 NSF SaTC PI Meeting. Outreach beyond academia included participation in the Arizona Tech Showcase and ASU Day at the Arizona Capitol. The research team was selected for a visit from the U.S. Department of State’s International Visitor Leadership Program (IVLP) delegation on cyberbullying (comprised of scholars and policy experts from Eastern Europe and Central Asia). The project also contributed to meaningful conversations about cyberbullying though media coverage within the region (e.g., Arizona’s CBS, NBC Phoenix, KTAR Radio, Arizona PBS, AZFamily, Cronkite News) and at ASU across multiple formats (e.g., TV, radio, web).

Additional information, including links to media coverage of the project, can be found at the project’s website: http://bullyblocker.asu.edu.
